moves.3... Qe7: Queen coming out early, must get the Horses out to greet her.
moves.4... c6: c5 meant to discourage any diagonal for the White Bishop or a Fork Check on the King at c7.
moves.5. Bc4: I get the Priest out in prep for Castling Kingside.
moves.5... h6: h6 to discourage an attack on the f-Pawn.
moves.7. Bb3: A safe, quiet place to wait.
moves.7... Bg4: Bishop pinning the Knight to my Queen, telegraphs the Black King's intent to Castle on the opposite wing.
moves.8. O-O: Hoping to control the f-File, but g3 is a perilously weakened square.
moves.8... Nd7: Strange place for the Queen's Knight.
moves.9... cxd5: Knight before Bishop on this option.
moves.10. Nxd5: Knight attacks the middle, and the Lady.
moves.11... O-O-O: A mistake to not play Nf6.
moves.12. Bxf4: The other Bishop forces her to run.
moves.12... Qa6: A premature attack on the Black Queen, but the horse can reside safely for a moment at a6.
moves.13. Nc7: Another free Pawn resides at f7.
moves.13... Qa5: She is theatening the Knight in return.
moves.14. Na8: But a Knight in the corner is a goner!
moves.14... Nb6: A Knight attacks a Knight. Starting to lose the script a little bit here.
moves.15. Bc7: Not a forceful move in any sense.
moves.16. Qe2: Hoping that I can catch a superior player in a mistake.
moves.16... Re7: And now the tables are turned, my Queen is pushed back.
moves.18. Qc4+: Gives her a chance to escape, yet she still is in danger.
moves.18... Nc7: Deciding against capturing the Knight and trading Queens.
moves.20. d6: Passed Pawns prefer to be pushed.
moves.20... Rxe5: Trading for the Knight, apologies to my Bishop!
moves.21. dxc7: Why no capture the Pawn now?
moves.21... Bd5: Remember I was hoping for a trap ...
moves.22. Qd4: It would be better for the King to capture the Pawn.
moves.22... Bxb3: But Black will pay for the greed!
moves.23. Qd8#: Undeveloped Kingside dooms the Dark Side!
